comments.body: [Python documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/datastructures.html) says that `del dirs[:]` is equivalent to `dirs.clear()`. Just out of curiosity is there a reason to use the former? Is it faster maybe?
`clear()` does not seem to exist in py2.7

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +438,442 @@                        if depth > params['depth']:
                            # Empty the list used by os.walk to avoid traversing deeper unnecessarily
                            del(dirs[:])
                            continue
                    if os.path.basename(fsname).startswith('.') and not params['hidden']:

comments.body:
I think it'd be clearer what it does if you name it like this
```suggestion
def raise_walk_error(e):
```
(it'd be more obvious when used in the code below)
it really does both `handle_walk_error_by_reraising'  was a bit too long

I think this'd read better with a bit of semantic naming:
```suggestion
            for root, dirs, files in os.walk(npath, onerror=raise_walk_error, followlinks=params['follow']):
```
